item.title: Contact
item.dc:creator: juliusreade
item.content:encoded: A large portion of my day is spent talking to people about their mental health issues (though usually my problems as well), be it with my friends or strangers over the internet. I find the intimacy attractive and we always end up learning something each other and so it is always a valuable experience. While I maintain that the best way to understand something is to study it inside and out, not everyone has that sort of privilege. Often the simple act of talking to someone about your issues can produce profoundly meaningful results. If you would like to know a little bit more about me and this website, please read my about page. I currently do not charge for advice and I am more than happy to respond to your email or via the contact form below: julius@perspectivetheory.com [contact-form]

item.title: About
item.dc:creator: juliusreade
item.content:encoded:
My name is Julius Reade. I am a freelance writer from Melbourne Australia. I use this website as an outlet to write about the manifestations of delusion and the ways it can encompass our lives. My other significant projects include The Zero Hedge Daily Round Up and The Financial Reality. I completed my Bachelor of Journalism at Monash University in 2014.

About myself and this website.

I am a very curious person and my personality has always driven me to seek answers within my own life and others. I am a very self-driven individual which is why I have sought a qualified mental health professional. I created this website with the intention of catering to other self-driven individuals, who intuitively want to understand how their mind works. People approach psychologists with the idea in mind that they can provide them with answers. Ultimately, it is those who understand that only they have the answers and authority to their questions, which will deal with mental illness most effectively. Much human emotional suffering is unwarranted, yet it may exist in our lives without second thought. We either presume that we do not have the power to change who we are or that these traits are temporary and I hope this website can prove these notions incorrect.

Why I write perspective well.

The reason why I am an efficient perspective writer is a) because I have a lot of experience and knowledge with mental health issues and b) because of the way my mind interprets information. I have one great flaw as a person. I have an incomplete memory. I can barely remember what happened yesterday, let alone one week ago. All these memories are absent in my mind, though they can still be recalled after a concentrated effort. As a result, I am forgetful of the bad and harmful logic in my mind. The assumptions, the judgments, the expectations of self-worth etc. These are qualities that have been instilled into the physical structure of my brain and perspective is the only thing preventing them from exaggerating and wrecking havoc to my mental health. However because I am forgetful, this is a futile act. Inevitably I become overwhelmed after a period of time, as it is impossible to remember everything and the cycle starts again. Also in order to successfully create the required perspective I need for each day and/or situation, I need to spend at least a few hours each day writing and sorting through my logic and unfortunately, I do not always have the time. So naturally, I have become very good at processing my thoughts and understanding the faulty assumptions that people use to underpin their beliefs. It also means that I have become amazing at improvising perspective, simply because I've gone through it so many times before.

Why self-awareness?

I believe in the method of self-awareness as an effective tool to help alleviate emotional suffering. To a large extent, it is very difficult to change who we are. While I do believe it is possible to change our beliefs, and certainly I have changed many, I believe it is ultimately counter-productive because our personality tends to revert back to the person who we feel we should be, even if it is benign and destructive. The alternative is to understand who we are and what is required to keep our checks and balances in place. I argue that a majority of the emotional pain we experience is because of the logical inconsistencies and fallacies that we create for ourselves. It is the basis for all the poor judgments, faulty assumptions, frustration, sadness etc. With perspective we can hope to understand and expose this bad logic and come to a consensus. I believe our mental illness is a facet of logic, because I would continually fall into depression and experience negative emotional reactions, until I started questioning and understanding the way I think.

Is self-awareness for everyone?

It's important to understand that self-awareness is merely a tool. The effectiveness of how you use it is up to you. I believe it has the potential to prevent mental illness, though the stage of your recovery and your own understanding of who you are, will also affect how you can use it. Perspective is a form of self-awareness and it requires an understanding of logic to grasp. While some of the logic in my articles can be complex, I also cover basic emotional logic, such as how we make judgments and even how we focus. Unfortunately, some people don't like to think about their problems. They like to hide away and slip down into the rabbit hole while the world around them ceases to exist. These are the ones I cannot help directly, especially since I am not there in person.

Inspiration for the website.

Often you will see so-called 'happy' people who are incredibly judgmental or people who may be considered 'successful' yet are also completely miserable with their lives. With self-awareness, not only can we reverse these trends, however we can experience the clarity of our emotions without confusion or conflict. As you can probably imagine I suffer from a lot of mental health issues. Most of my friends have issues as well so I've been able to observe the spectrum of insanity over the years. People with severe drug addictions, crippling insecurities, incessant thoughts of suicide, a complete absence of emotion - you name it. The tipping point for me however, was the aftermath of my first relationship with a girl who was also mentally ill. The outcome was particularly tragic and from that point on, I decided to dedicate my life to understanding my own mental illness, as well as the mental illness of others. I now feel like I have enough perspective in my life to lead a happy existence and I learn more about myself everyday. Of course, perspective is merely a way of reorganizing our thoughts and understanding of who we are. Happiness itself is jut a simple, pleasurable emotion.

Questions!

If you have any questions, queries or advice that you would like to give me, then please feel free to shoot me an email or via this contact form. I am more than happy to respond: julius@perspectivetheory.com [contact-form]

item.title: All it takes is a healthy perspective
item.dc:creator: juliusreade
item.content:encoded:
My name is Julius Reade, and I've created this website to help people better understand themselves and their mental health issues. I write about the ways in which we make life unnecessarily difficult for ourselves, the context and functions behind these manifestations, and the techniques required to successfully break away from these mental cycles and embrace the beauty that life has to offer. You can access my blog here.

We live in a world of...

Acute stress. Depression. Judgmental attitudes. Crippling insecurity. Social anxiety. Blinding cynicism. Feelings of unworthiness. Focused limitations. Low self-esteem. Fear. Internal rumination. Abusive relationships. Restlessness. Obsessive compulsive disorders. Intellectual dishonesty. Chasing fame. Negative thoughts. Hysteria. Self-reinforced delusion. Perceptions of failure. Ineffective coping mechanisms. Negative reactions. Unobtainable perfectionism. Logical fallacies. Deep-seated Pessimism. Drug abuse. Addiction. Absent gratitude. Guilt. Poor lifestyle. Manipulative behaviors. Unobtainable focus. Arrogance. Inner agitation. Never-ending grief. Emotional suffering. Broken agreements. Superiority complexes. Struggling with reality. Cognitive dissonance. Shame. Clinging to hope. Taking events personally. Self-criticism. Jadedness. Life without passion. Lost motivation. Self-hatred. Sleeplessness. Denial. Mental illness. Internal confusion. Irrational anger. Frustration. Incessant comparison.
...and we repeat these vicious cycles over and over again, like an irreversible curse. We are affected by these cycles every hour, from the moment we wake up until the moment we fall asleep. The sad thing is that a lot of people don't realise - all these things are entirely preventable. This is the dangerous and confusing world of everyone's mind. I used to be every one of those things described above: I used to suffer from depression; I used to be very confused and hurt about life, yet to me, it was all just an everyday occurrence. You don't question what feels inherently "normal". Thankfully, I have two very contradictory benefits as a person that helped me break these cycles and understand how these damaging behaviors work. Firstly, I never give up no matter how badly I'm beaten and secondly, I always learn the hard way. I trial and error every single experience, good and bad, before I find the strength to finally move on from the pain. While this may seem like a recipe for disaster, it also allows for personal leverage to grasp, toy and manipulate with the way these delusions manifest. It also means that I no longer suffer helplessly from these symptoms. It doesn't mean that I'm immune to letting these cycles recur, however this is one of the beauties of self-awareness. It allows you to consistently understand the way you function and how best to enhance your life. You can access my blog here.

What is self-awareness?

It's helpful to visualise self-awareness as a mental framework to understanding who you are and how your personality and biology conflict to create your entire mental state. Self-awareness is not like a Band-Aid for a quick-fix, and it cannot instantly and permanently prevent you from feeling depressed or confused about life. Self-awareness can, however, provide you with a powerful methodological and cognitive process to help you change for the better and give you tools to cope with the worst. It is a secure stepping stone towards addressing the cognitive dissonances in our thoughts, feelings, behaviours and emotions. More succinctly, self-awareness is a framework for description. You may not quite know it yet, but words and language are fundamental to the way we process information, especially regarding how we feel and think. The great thing about self-awareness is that it's completely personal, and equally effective of understanding and communicating thought. Self-awareness is something that grows over time. There's always more and more to learn about yourself and the way nature functions and effects you. The longer you take the time to study self-awareness, the more you'll discover about the essence of humanity- the way we think and feel, as well as every other factor that happens to encompass reality.
Choices lead to behaviors. Behaviors lead to habits. Habits lead to character.
Ultimately, we’re all shaped by what we believe in. Our beliefs help us form the basis of the images and understanding of people and normalcy, as well the thoughts and behaviors we rely on to function. Once we become aware of our beliefs and identities, we can learn how to change who we are almost effortlessly. Understanding our beliefs can help us discover how our crippling insecurities are formed; our issues with low self-esteem; the ways in which we lose our passion for life - we seemingly focus on our limitations, live in a world of self-criticism and judgment, take every minute detail personally, as well as every other victimisation with force upon ourselves on a daily basis. By learning to become self-aware, we can finally take our mental health seriously with an approach that neither gives nor takes.
With the correct technique anyone can learn, or unlearn, anything.
Many of us think our emotions are ultimately irrational, however it’s actually our harmful beliefs and the false images that affect the way we think, behave, and feel. Our negative emotions are a consequence of a broken system of belief. Even if we have good intentions for ourselves, which most of us do, without a proper technique and framework we cannot truly hope to change who we are. One pianist can spend 40 years learning a difficult piece and still not be able to play it properly, yet a similarly skilled pianist can learn the same piece within a few weeks. Technique and framework are the basis of talent; talent itself never stands on it's own. You can access my blog here.

Personal responsibility for our mental health

You see, most are actually quite impartial to having negative thoughts on any number of disorders that plague our society. I don't take the view that these behaviors are inherently bad things - I merely see them as a by-product of the way we think and behave. Humans are misguided; sometimes intentionally, other times unintentionally. Self-awareness isn't a system of morals, of good and bad. Self-awareness is about understanding the acceptance and responsibility that we owe to ourselves, if we're ever to change the way we feel, think and behave. We don't suffer needlessly because we're bad people. We never mean harm. I personally didn't even know I was depressed and dysfunction until much later in life. I thought all these behaviors were normal and that anyone not suffering was plain and simple. In a sense, I thought everyone was sad without acknowledging it. It wasn't until I'd reached my breaking point, that I'd decided to discover a new way of thinking. Through self-awareness, I was able to observe these behaviors for what they truly were and give myself a chance to breathe. It gave me the power and responsibility to change myself, however I liked.
There's an epiphany most people go through when they start thinking about the way their problems work. They read an article on jealousy or judgmental attitudes and their mind flashes. "Oh my gosh, that's exactly how it works and I'm exactly that person!"
Naturally, changing after a lifetime of reinforced and destructive habits isn't a simple process. I certainly didn't change overnight, and there was a lot of resistance to freeing the tension in my mind. Yet we all get there in the end if we give ourselves a chance. I know I did, even though many won't. This is why I wanted to make a make a website to give people a better chance at becoming self-aware; to learn with ease and passion. You can access my blog here.

Mental health for a 21st century

My articles are designed to help you understand, not only how we form these behaviors, but the resistance involved and how best to approach them. Through my articles, you will learn about how these thought patterns arise and the ways in which they exaggerate over time to become abusive, unholy shires in our minds. It will be an epiphany for many of you - an answer to the functioning of your suffering. There's one saying that I particularly like, which I think echos what mental health is about. Put simply, being ignorant of our actions and reality, does not lessen the consequences of these actions. Repeating offensive behaviors with good intentions, is still going to produce an offensive outcome.
Self-awareness is an important life skill because it has the potential to prevent continued emotional suffering and pain for as long as you choose.
Imagine all the time spent being frustrated and angry- all those days lost and irritated. All those days mired in sadness and loneliness. This website aims to cover everything you need to help and understand yourself. It takes a special kind of courage to attempt the seemingly impossible, but without our dreams, we are nothing but empty shells, with hope only as a mere afterthought. I’ve written more than 300 articles detailing the issues and dilemmas that people suffer from daily. The logic behind these dilemmas certainly aren't complex; it's only once they form into habit do they slide into our consciousness and blend into the exterior of our hearts. Once we become consciously aware of what we're truly doing to ourselves, not only acknowledging our problems, but understanding the way they function, then and only then will change come naturally thereafter. Of course, it's a lot easier said that done. Nothing worth doing in life is easy, but that doesn't mean it can't be enjoyable. Ask yourself, is your mental health your number one priority? What are the long term consequences of not focusing on your mental health? Only you have the power to decide. You can access my blog here.

Making a commitment to your happiness today

I remember making a commitment to myself, a few months prior to my birthday. I was in complete shambles. My break up had completely decimated my will to live, I'd nearly overdosed on a research chemical which had lead to hospitalisation, and my life was reduced to crying in bed for as long as the tears would flow. It was a very difficult time, but it was also a turning point for me in my life. I'd decided to make a commitment to myself, a commitment I would never walk away from:
I was going to do absolutely everything in my power to be a happy individual, no matter what.
I made this commitment, and I've never looked back. It may very well be the smartest decision of your entire life. While finding the courage to approach your life with intent may seem difficult, is any more difficult than spending the rest of your life living in perpetual pain? As for me, it was a complicated journey, but here I stand today - a proud subject and happy to be alive and thankful for every second of it. And you can feel the same. You can access my blog here.

item.title: The Trauma Narrative - GT - JEDIT
item.dc:creator: juliusreade
item.content:encoded:
We have all suffered from trauma to some extent. The word trauma derives from the word 'wound' in Greek. When we experience trauma, we feel like we have been wounded in some way. It could be a past event that has deeply offended us or rendered us to feel worthless or like a failure. Often trauma is very subtle. It does not have to be necessarily physical or sexual in nature to be extreme, for a lot of people it is psychological in nature. Either from neglect or past perceptions of themselves. However truama does not necessarily have to be a bad thing. When we are wounded, it does not mean that we are broken. I take the view that trauma is only painful if it is not properly addressed, like an open wound without a bandage. Our traumas can heal with time and perspective, however only if we address it properly. In that sense it helps to think of trauma as a grievance without redress. An event that we have not learnt or gained perspective from, so to keep us from playing the cycle again in our minds.

Trauma in our lives.

It can help to understand how trauma makes us feel. Tragedy and trauma present us with a whole range of fatal misconceptions that play out as horrible scenarios in our mind. It is an aspect of our personality which deeply offends us, yet shines like a dark beacon amongst a sea of almost intangible thought. Trauma takes away from those principles we hope to instill within ourselves, by substituting with it's own foundations of safety and trust. It aims to distort our previously subconscious ideas of how best to protect ourselves from the reality around us. After a prolonged period of time, we may not even remember what these principles are and for many people, these ideal principle never existed in the first place. The problem is that our trauma tries to teach us and guide us using a faulty set of assumptions, plagued by our memories and thoughts from the past. If you had a madman constantly standing outside your window, shouting at you not to the leave the house, the chances are you probably wouldn't. For some people, that madman current exists in reality via an abusive partner, stalker etc. though for others, the madman exists solely in our minds.

Changing our trauma.

Naturally, I can only offer advice to those who are currently in a safe environment, yet are still experiencing the pains of the past. If you are in danger, then there is very little these words can do to physically help you. However this also doesn't mean you have to be weak in your mind. There are a lot of techniques that can help you from from taking trauma personally, though often it can just lead to prolonged delusion. Back to the originally query, how can we possibly display courage if we are so mired by fear? On the one hand, we like to keep our trauma close to us because it feels uniquely ours. It holds us ransom in our mind to fear from the past, because it's now fabricated presence seems crucial and furthermore, integral to our own personality and survival. Our trauma constantly reminds us of who we are, or rather who we seem to be, even if we don’t agree with it. It is a disastrous perversion of our own perception and self-identity.

Addressing our trauma.

Since we are attached to our trauma in some way, it can be very difficult to try and defeat this image. Naturally we look up to this image of the victim with high regard, because it's something we feel down to the very bone. Instead, we need to go a step further and question the logic . The reason we experienced trauma in the first place, is because of the faulty logic we used in the first place, which create the assumptions and opinions that we have of it today.

Where trauma gets tricky.

The hardest thing when dealing with trauma, is that not only do we have to deal with the underlying assumptions that our trauma manages to distort, however we also have to deal with the actual distortion staring us in the face. Because of the intensity of what we may experienced, we are already at a disadvantage at treating our wound. Our mind will come up with a million and one ways to deceive us, using the images of the past to haunt us and convince us that we are helpless. Of course, this is the central part of the challenge with dealing with trauma. It requires an integral amount of trust and certainly this allows ourselves to be taken advantage of, which is the real fear that most people suffering have - further being offend or experiencing trauma. . We may barely trust ourselves and many of us become in an attempt to try and stop the emotional pain, that we willingly attach to anything, bad relationships, bad advice, hopeless endeavours - just so we hope the pain will wash away. Even worse is that our trauma biases us towards certain ways of thinking and certain "solutions" which may ultimately be harmful for us and give our trauma more leverage over our lives. Especially if a mental health professional turns out to be dodgy. Of course, I can only hope to explain the dynamic of trauma and use that as a basis to gain trust. I hope my website can serve as a resource to help those suffering from depression and trauma, using advice that I personally gained to help my own.

item.title: A workable interpretation of the term mental illness
item.dc:creator: juliusreade
item.content:encoded:
One of the biggest issues with people suffering from mental illness is that there are an infinite number of ways for which to
 
In order to overcome your mental illness, it's going to require some reinterpretation of what mental illness is.
Put simply, the term mental illness is merely a description.
Ultimately, it's about giving yourself a choice to recover and overcome your issues. I once thought depression was a way of life... until I began changing the definitions of the way I saw things. Things like "this is simply a part of who I am" become "I may be like this, however it's not who I want to be".
There's always hope and thus solutions.

item.title: Learning to accept your circumstances
item.dc:creator: juliusreade
item.content:encoded:
In-spite of my circumstances, there was a time in my life where I felt severely underprivileged. I felt like a failure as a human being. I felt unwanted and lonely. I felt incapable of all the greatness that everyone around me seemed to project, even if it was a false expression of confidence and self-image.
Yet this was in-spite of my circumstances and the whole future I had ahead of me. I'm lucky enough to have a family to call home. I have arms and legs for which to work and produce things. I have so many things that people seemingly take for granted.
Life on the whole has been rather… turbulent, though by no means does this denote what privilege truly is: a mindset towards the way you look at life. You can have miserable rich people and miserable poor people, however privilege is just another construct, another limitation, that we create in our minds to prevent us from reaching our potential.
What you begin to realise is that circumstance is no excuse for how you feel. Granted you may be stuck in an abusive relationship or a
Even in these cases, that doesn’t in any way denote the privilege you have. Even if you’re stuck in your circumstances, doesn’t mean that you must remain.
The alternative is to cling onto hope and that will drive you insane. [link, clinging onto hope]

item.title: Self-awareness is more than just a mental process

item.title: Why the brain is designed to change
item.dc:creator: juliusreade
item.content:encoded: Ever since reading The Brain That Changes Itself, I’ve had a very different perspective on depression and the way it can be treated. Put simply, the brain is malleable and it is a plastic entity which can change however you like it. Victims of stroke, where the part of their brain that controls motor function is completely destroyed, can learn to move again by rewiring and relearning other parts of the brain to perform the same functions.   That’s pretty neat, huh? As this suggests our actions and behaviors are purely psychological, this understanding has also demonstrated that we can treat people with OCD, anxiety and depression, using similar tricks against the brain. OCD is a hardwired thought pattern that is reinforced neurally in your brain. The more you perform OCD like tendencies, the more you rewire the brain into these patterns of the thinking, the more attached and familiar you’ll become with these behaviors.   Likewise with cigarettes, just because they’re potentially addictive, does not mean that they   I remember reading a book while I was younger on the best technique in regards to learning piano. What the book suggested, is that as an effective way to practice piano is to actually imagine yourself playing the piano in your head in your free time. Since visualizing your actions activates the neural pathways in your mind, it’s just as effective as doing the actual things! In fact, studies have shown that imagining yourself lifting weights, produces muscle gain in subjects, though proportionally less than people lifting actual weights. Irregardless, it goes to show that the influence of the brain is significant when trying to describe our physical actions.   In a sense, all our particularities are « learned » behaviors, at least according to the brain. By no means am I doubting your trauma, yes, the outcomes are very real, but understand that the way you feel about yourself, is ultimately a learned process borne out of fear, desperation, insecurity etc.   What inhibits most people in their recovery, is not the technical solution itself, but rather the way people with depression perceive the very symptom itself.   The crux of this, is that the longer you spend doing something, the more effort it requires for change. That’s why I express a wide range of perspectives on this website, because your mind isn’t simply going to budge with the « right answer » in mind. You need to be continually budge and shifted, until finally that lid comes off and the freedom of your thoughts are not limited to the fear your mind seeks. http://www.amazon.fr/The-Brain-That-Changes-Itself/dp/0143113100

item.title: How we developed the judgmental mind
item.dc:creator: juliusreade
item.content:encoded:
We all make judgments in our everyday lives to evaluate the decisions we hope to make.
We traditionally do this by examining the evidence involved to make sure that our decisions best serve our interest. In other words, we make a lot of assumptions about the underlying fundamentals that will dictate our choice to make a decision. After a while however, we begin to generalise a lot of the assumptions because it is a lot simpler than meticulously examining everything and inquiring into the truth of the situation.
For example when we see a person in tattered clothes sitting on the side of a street, we generally assume that this person is homeless.
Problems begin to arise however, once we start to false assumptions because

Why we make judgments

It could be because of trauma.
It could be because we enjoy ignorance.
It could be because of the way we employ morals.
There's a very twisted duality that basic logic permits in our minds. It's the very basis for our culture, which is that predicated on the set of morals we were brought up with, this idea that our actions can either lead to good or bad results.
It's the system of logic that our parents used to motivate us and encourage us to either do good things and avoid bad.
If you did something good, then you were rewarded. If you did something bad, then you were punished. Of course, the rules were complete
reword the first paragraph
---------
It's a system of thought that's been hardwired into our brains and in order to process what is good and bad, we personally have been required to develop a system of judgment, so that we can make the 'right' choices in our lives that may be deemed appropriate or in some cases, intentionally inappropriate.
Why we make judgments.
We do things like exercise and help our friends, because they are branded as being 'good' in our minds. Which is fair enough, considering that we probably feel better for it. In this case, not only do we associate our actions with the moral (or the standard that we've created for ourselves or has been created for us), however we also associate our actions with the feeling that we recieve from them.
When we were younger however, our parents convinced us to do a lot of things that didn't necessarily make us happy or even feel good. What our parents would do is use threats to encourage us to just go along with the plan, with the reasoning in mind that the potential pain from 'misbehaving' will be seemingly more than that which you just endured through what you were told to do in the first place.
As I'm sure you can see, this is a very faulty, harmful and destructive way to teach any person to live their lives and is the reason for much of the mental illness we see today. This is because people continue to use this system of thought in order to teach themselves and people end up tripping over their logic without knowing it.
Incessant self-criticism and judgment? A keen hatred for the world? All these things are a simply byproduct of failing to employ emotional neutrality.
When our judgments turn sour.
We are not taught to enjoy life. Rather, we have been taught that through a system of abuse, we're able to seemingly convince ourselves to do things that we don't want to, like work or . In fact, we never even give ourselves the chance and opporunity to enjoy these things. In the process, we completely neglect our emotions
Because we have been taught that by
In return, we completely neglect our emotions and allow ourselves to be abused... by ourselves.
 made us do things that went against our emotions. However , they
Problems start to occur in our lives when
then
In fact it's incredibly difficult for us to even understand the very concept of neutrality, simply because our minds have not been primed to understand it.
It's best to equate

 (c)XXXXX How we fall into judgement.
How judgmental attitudes affect our wellbeing.
How judgmental attitudes negatively affect our wellbeing.
Why judgmental attitudes hinder us.
The ways which judgmental attitudes hinder us.
Why judgmental attitudes are a framework for self-hatred
Why judgmental attitudes always lead to self-hatred
The rampant
  • Judgement is a framework and attitude as a result of self-image.
  • Reasons why judgement is bad.
The reason why judgemental attitudes manage to trap us and grow worse over time, is because the transition of becoming judgemental is very subtle and benign. We don’t have the awareness to realise how they harm us, until things become too late. Even then, some people remain so full of hate and judgemental that they continue to cultivate the pain and suffering until it completely consumes them. This is why learning to accept humility can go a very long way.
Judgemental attitudes are like a double-edged sword. The statements we make give us a sense of power and wisdom, because it is a sense of self-righteousness. It is impossible to make a false judgement in our minds. The reason why we make judgements in the first place, is because we have this image of ourselves, this identity, which reminds us that we should always be right, no matter what the expense. When we make an incorrect judgement however, we take it personally and we compare ourselves with the ideal in our mind that we should be right. This leads to self-criticism and self-judgement.
As long as we have an image of ourselves of who we are in our mind, we will always let our thoughts sabotage us. We will always learn to take everything personally and give up our power to our thoughts, irregardless if it’s in our best interest. We live our life through negative emotional reactions.
We become perfectionists who always manage to disappoint ourselves and cynics who increasingly become hateful of the world. Accurate descriptions of reality do not require judgemental attitudes and they give up our own personal power to think clearly and critically. This is because judgements are not driven by our desire for the truth, but by the image of who we think we should be in our minds. We allow our thoughts to limit us with the intention of giving us power. The strive for perfectionism is always going to result in failure and self-criticism.
Another reasons why judgements can be harmful is that we cannot make a distinction between our judgements and our thoughts. When we make a judgement such as "Oh wow, that person is really ugly », the thought is neurally reinforced in our minds [The importance of neutrality], much in the same way that thinking about performing a motion, such as throwing a ball, activates the part of the motor cortex associated with that movement. Excessive judgements can lead to OCD and other behaviours.
Judgements are dangerous because they are self-reinforcing and simple emotions and behaviours such as anger and sadness become distorted to the point of becoming abusive and harmful. We believe it’s the negative emotions that drive us, when really it’s the mindset which traps us into our own negativity. This arises because of the belief that we need to be judgemental to have self-worth. We depend on it for our values.
Ambitions are fundamental to our passion for life, however judgemental attitudes and inner identities do not serve as direct solutions to cultivating passion. Instead, if we are going to live a life free of self-criticism and self-rejection, then we must focus on changing our emotions by dissolving the images in our mind and changing the core beliefs behind these images. Through awareness of these issues, we can learn to understand how we sabotage ourselves emotionally and intellectually. This can be achieved by signing up to my self-awareness course and practicing the exercises to help you achieve your goals without negative reactions.

item.title: The most important piece of advice for people suffering from depression
item.dc:creator: juliusreade
item.content:encoded:
The most important piece of advice for people suffering from depression   Last night I was talking to this severely depressed person and I think it was interesting to witness the sort of cynicism and attitudes that depressed people display. There was a lot of fear and misconception of what mental illness is and who they are, which I tend to find is quite common. Depressed people are usually quite skeptical about recovering from their own mental illness, which is why it is bad to give a depressed person optimism, even though funnily enough optimism is the end result of overcoming mental illness. It feels as if they have already accepted their sad state of affairs, yet are ultimately confused and desperate to change. One the one hand, they are not willing to give themselves the chance, yet a chance is what they pray for to come and save them. Which I think is fair enough, however I would just like to talk about some of fallacies and notions that depressed people have.

The first step towards recovery.

Here is what I would like to say to people currently suffering from mental illness: I want you to assume that everything you know about yourself, your mental illness, your life, your thoughts, your emotions - is all completely and entirely wrong. The reason I say we should assume we should assume that everything we know is completely wrong, is because this is an inherent trait of a skeptic. It is what we should strive for. Yet when we become skeptical and eventually take personally, the different points of view towards what other people believe depression is, yet defend our own conceptions of what depression is - then we are hardly skeptical. We are merely cynics and idealists in disguise. The sad thing with most depressed people is that they are mostly cynics pretending to be skeptics. Depression will do that to you and hence which it is common referred to as a sort of delusion. In addition, I say this because there is in fact, there is nothing wrong with your mental illness. It does not have good or bad qualities, it is simply an aspect of nature and you can either work with nature or against it. Rejecting the nature will only help in diminishing your influence   The cynicism of depression solutions. There is a lot of skepticism over the prospect of overcoming depression. Part of the reason is because we do not even know what depression and mental illness is. Can it be overcome? Is it even possible to overcome or is it something we live with and learn to manage for the rest of our lives? You tell them how you've managed to control your mental health and then they   Presume that everything you know about depression is completely wrong. How did you get control of it? How did it become a choice? Is everyone the same? Depression is a multifaceted concept. If circumstantial, then the cause is obvious. If clinical, then it's because we're confused.   Depression is more than just negative thinking and a lack of perspective. - Chemical Imbalance, excess in one and not in another. Internal reasons and external reasons (self-esteem): These things exacerbate the effects of depression, but the underlying cause is the chemical imbalance. ME: The chemical imbalance is a symptom, rather than the cause. Just like how tiredness is a symptom of over working yourself.  What is a symptom and what is a cause. I believe we are focusing on all the wrong areas - People are so pent up on changing their symptoms, rather than the cause of these symptoms, that they complete confuse and misunderstand what depression is.   For clinical depression, you must have five or more of the following symptoms over a two-week period, most of the day, nearly every day.   clinical depression, circumstantial depression, unipolar depression, bipolar depression, social anxiety disorder. Perspective doesn't care about the label which describes our symptoms. All it cares about is the cause   We get so pent up with the terms and the labels and all that. Let's take a step back. Let's not trap ourselves into terms we barely understand.   At the end of the day we need to focus on the basics, our emotions, our thoughts and our beliefs. These are the building blocks to our experience. Labels are just a way of generalising how we feel, so that we can create the perception that things will be more managable. If we give our feelings and thoughts this name of "depression" then it's like it just legitimises our feelings and packages them into a brand we feel like we can recognise and not feel so alienated with who we are. It is dangerous and presumptous. Depression is an illness. It is like people are out of control. To suggest that it could be prevented should someone have the choice, is to imply they have a choice at all. Are they really incontrol. This idea of want vs able. Analogy: If someone breaks their leg, no matter how much they WANT to walk, they aren't going to be able to physically do it. People don't realise what they're capable of, until they've overcome their depression. It's a lot like wishing that you did more with your life, yet you can't quite gather the motivation to do anything, so it reinforces this idea of wanting more without taking the responsibility.   I find a lot of this logic to be circular. Instead, I like to look towards role models and inspirations. I believe in human ability above all. People are depressed because they've made an incorrect assumption about their lives. They are inherently wrong. Certainly, there is nothing wrong with depression, because depression is a simple facet of nature. It exists because of how we mingle with nature. You can either work against or in favour with our emotions.       There's this idea that help is a simple process that requires trust and action. I think it takes time.

item.title: How Humans Create Emotional Pain
item.dc:creator: juliusreade
item.content:encoded:
Some people suffer from mental health issues on a regular basis. Certainly they are not deserving of blame for suffering. The hardest part is often learning to love ourselves, regardless of who we are or how our mental health affects our everyday lives. One of the reasons why perspective is particularly helpful for me is because I have a very elusive memory. I can barely remember what happened yesterday and I certainly have no recollection of anything before that. I become shortsighted in my decisions and behaviours. I will have an epiphany about how my emotional suffering came to light and then immediately forget it the next day. It's funny because I'm also incredibly knowledgeable and what I've come to discover, is that what I lack in my ability to recall information, I make up in my ability to improvise information. That is what makes this website work - I have the ability to improvise perspective, which is how I get through my mental health issues. Given that perspective is such a wonderful tool for people hoping to understand their mental illness, it has occurred to me that I still suffer from mental illness on a continual basis, even though I understand how it all functions in my mind. I believe we suffer because we continually forget or neglect the reasons why, though naturally it depends at what stage you are in your recovery. \

The cycle of depression.

Arguably if you are in an abusive or undesirable environment, then perspective and self-awareness will have a limited effect changing how you feel. Not because these tools cannot help achieve those things, but because they are primarily designed to help understand how your mental illness functions, rather than change who you are. It is from knowing and being aware, that we're able to change our beliefs of who we are. This is very difficult achieve in a turbulent environment, and this advice won't be particularly useful for those people. The difficult part with changing your beliefs as well, is that there is so much potential trauma in life that our beliefs would need to constantly change, which is a very difficult and laborious. At the very least, we should change the limiting beliefs we have of ourself.

item.title: When we depend on others for our emotional well being.
item.dc:creator: juliusreade
juliusreade
item.content:encoded:
(c)XXXXX How we fall into judgement.
How judgmental attitudes affect our wellbeing.
How judgmental attitudes negatively affect our wellbeing.
Why judgmental attitudes hinder us.
The ways which judgmental attitudes hinder us.
Why judgmental attitudes are a framework for self-hatred
Why judgmental attitudes always lead to self-hatred
The rampant
  • Judgement is a framework and attitude as a result of self-image.
  • Reasons why judgement is bad.
The reason why judgemental attitudes manage to trap us and grow worse over time, is because the transition of becoming judgemental is very subtle and benign. We don’t have the awareness to realise how they harm us, until things become too late. Even then, some people remain so full of hate and judgemental that they continue to cultivate the pain and suffering until it completely consumes them. This is why learning to accept humility can go a very long way.
Judgemental attitudes are like a double-edged sword. The statements we make give us a sense of power and wisdom, because it is a sense of self-righteousness. It is impossible to make a false judgement in our minds. The reason why we make judgements in the first place, is because we have this image of ourselves, this identity, which reminds us that we should always be right, no matter what the expense. When we make an incorrect judgement however, we take it personally and we compare ourselves with the ideal in our mind that we should be right. This leads to self-criticism and self-judgement.
As long as we have an image of ourselves of who we are in our mind, we will always let our thoughts sabotage us. We will always learn to take everything personally and give up our power to our thoughts, irregardless if it’s in our best interest. We live our life through negative emotional reactions.
We become perfectionists who always manage to disappoint ourselves and cynics who increasingly become hateful of the world. Accurate descriptions of reality do not require judgemental attitudes and they give up our own personal power to think clearly and critically. This is because judgements are not driven by our desire for the truth, but by the image of who we think we should be in our minds. We allow our thoughts to limit us with the intention of giving us power. The strive for perfectionism is always going to result in failure and self-criticism.
Another reasons why judgements can be harmful is that we cannot make a distinction between our judgements and our thoughts. When we make a judgement such as "Oh wow, that person is really ugly », the thought is neurally reinforced in our minds [The importance of neutrality], much in the same way that thinking about performing a motion, such as throwing a ball, activates the part of the motor cortex associated with that movement. Excessive judgements can lead to OCD and other behaviours.
Judgements are dangerous because they are self-reinforcing and simple emotions and behaviours such as anger and sadness become distorted to the point of becoming abusive and harmful. We believe it’s the negative emotions that drive us, when really it’s the mindset which traps us into our own negativity. This arises because of the belief that we need to be judgemental to have self-worth. We depend on it for our values.
Ambitions are fundamental to our passion for life, however judgemental attitudes and inner identities do not serve as direct solutions to cultivating passion. Instead, if we are going to live a life free of self-criticism and self-rejection, then we must focus on changing our emotions by dissolving the images in our mind and changing the core beliefs behind these images. Through awareness of these issues, we can learn to understand how we sabotage ourselves emotionally and intellectually. This can be achieved by signing up to my self-awareness course and practicing the exercises to help you achieve your goals without negative reactions.

item.title: Why the diagnosis of clinical depression is flawed
item.dc:creator: juliusreade

item.title: Why we should not reject society.
item.dc:creator: juliusreade
item.content:encoded:
Why it is ineffective to reject society. Society makes people feel a whole range of different emotions and thoughts. A lot of people completely loath society for what it has become. They hate the rampant consumerism, the seeming stupidity of the masses and the typical arrogance of the self-absorbed individual. Of course there are many other variations of society and while I do not deny their truth, I simply believe there is a more effective way to live. People with great ambitions or alternative ideas are generally impeded by their emotions, well before they are able to influence the world around them. They become mired in hate or optimism, rendering them delusion to the very people they are trying to change. It is one thing to feel detest, how to effectively act on it is a completely different issue.

Why our emotions are not are not effective change.

A lot of people act of their emotions to drive them. When they get really The problem is that not only are these judgments based upon faulty assumptions, however they also diminish our true purpose of effectively creating responsbility and influence with which to change society.

Introducing empathy.

Empathy is a rare quality. It is about understanding what another person is feeling and experiencing. Even more rare however, is learning to empathise with ourselves. We become so absorbed with who we are and our own individuals thoughts of what society and reality should be, that we forget that these are just thoughts. Once we let our emotions to dictate us for long enough, we can even forget that they are thoughts to begin with. In a sense, we are exploiting our own empathy, rather than taking advantage of the empathy of others to inflict change. It is an easy way of coping, rather than projecting.

Do not take society personally.

Many of us feel like society is out of our control and this frustrates us. We wish we could be some sort of benevolent dictator, controlling every individual cog for our needs. It is not an unreasonable desire, however it is an impractical one. People become so obsessed with their ideology, that they forget they are still a part of society. They forget that they are one of the cogs in the system. Possibly the best thing we can do is remain calm and perhaps more importantly, not take our points of view personally. Understandably many issues may

item.title: Our thoughts are the only thing holding us together
item.dc:creator: juliusreade
item.content:encoded:
The importance of our thoughts.
When you think about the structure of the mind, there are a few elements that bring it all together.
There are our emotions which allow us to feel reality. There are our beliefs which give reality structure. There are our bodily senses that allow us to perceive reality. Yet above all, there are our thoughts which allow us to process our emotions, our beliefs and our senses into something workable.
Without our thoughts, we have nothing. We have no control. We have no rationality. We have no humanity.
Unfortunately this is the default state of many people. They allow their emotions to control who they are. I believe a lot of mental illness is the result of neglecting our thoughts, in favour for our emotions, beliefs and senses. I also believe that as long as we can think and maintain contact with our thoughts, then we can take control of our mental illness.

Why our thoughts should have full authority.

While our beliefs are the rulers of our mind, our thoughts are like the citizens of society. Our thoughts are always ultimately responsible for the way we organise our mind and dictate, even if we have very tyrannous rulers.
For many people, this is quite true. They have belief structures predicated upon fear and insecurity. There is no freedom in their thoughts, due to trauma from the past. Their thoughts are not free to experience and explore, out of fear of harm and punishment.
It may be that certainly

How to reclaim power to our thoughts.

In ordert to

item.title: Aspiring towards something greater.
item.dc:creator: juliusreade
item.content:encoded:
I think most people aspire towards something greater in life.
We may not notice it or be conscious of it, however with the basic desire to survive, is the desire to grow. We usually equate this with the metaphysical sense of having more - wealth, knowledge, experiences etc.
It is the aspirations that we have in life which give it meaning.
Are there bad aspirations?
There are a diverse range of views on what constitutes growth.

item.title: Why we should not buy into authority
item.dc:creator: juliusreade
item.content:encoded:
Society is structured in such away that we have many positions of authority.
In fact, our entire existence seems predicated on some form of authority. Our parents, the government, even the knowledge and information we consume on a daily basis.
This idea of authority is so ingrained into our society, that few of us dare question it. Authority simply exists to guide us and protect us from ourselves. Arguable, few of us truly understand how authority works, which is why we allow it to abuse us and take advantage of us.
While fear is a primary reason, one of the subconscious reasons we abide to authority is because we treat it like a role model - just like our parents and our leaders.
We treat authority like a god and so thus we aspire towards authority. We too, want to be in higher positions of authority, so we neglect the responsibility we have to society and ourselves
.
What is authority?
What  people don’t realise is that authority is created. We are not born with authority, but rather, we are born with responsibility to authority.
Authority not only exists in people, but in the way we think, in the knowledge we subscribe to, in our beliefs, as well as a range of different things.
We have the responsibility to follow, as well as disown authority. Authority is like a guide of sorts that we can choose to follow and neglect.
The issue is that many of us don’t follow this sort of logic. Instead, we give up entirely to authority and allow it to corrupt our sense of responsibility - the responsibility that we owe to ourselves.
As a result, we end up placing a lot of authority into others and not into ourselves. This creates a lot of problems for ourselves.
This leads us down a very dangerous path, both emotionally and logically.
We tend to give authority more power than it actually has. Authority begins to manifest into something which
The worst thing is that we allow it to happen to ourselves. We give people the right of opinion over us, people who may be
How we developed to understand authority.
We were dictated by authority as children because we lacked choice. We simply did not have the knowledge, responsiblity or the experience to exert authority and certainly, we did not want to.
As we got older however, we encountered new forms of higher authority.
The problems of abdicating authority.
One of these issues is that we give power to labels.
We do not see each other as equal human beings with the same capacities. Authority creates hierarchy and many people associate this hierarchy with their self-worth. This is one way to create a lot of arrogance and emotional pain in our lives.
Another result is that we place less emphasis on our own abilities. We neglect that we are equally capable as human beings. We give up our opinions to people with labels, because apparnte
When there is no skepticism, then we are easily abused and taken advantage of. When there is cynicism and idealism on the other hand, it tends to reinforce authority
Having a true respect for authority.
I do believe that authority can be warranted. I do not believe authority itself is necessarily a bad thing. It is also possible to have too much authority into ourselves.
What I am suggesting is that people need to understand authority in order to allow it to function
Thankfully because of the internet, authority is now back in our hands where we can dictate how to issue our own responsibilities.
Authority is something based in faith.
These are create positions
